properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain at times heavy, and possible thunderstorms producing significant rainfall amounts expected tonight. A north to south band of very heavy rainfall with embedded thunderstorms has intensified over portions of the area early this evening. This band is also rather slow moving, so some areas within the warning region may see well in excess of 50 mm. The heaviest rain will taper to light showers later tonight. However, the shower activity will likely continue into Wednesday. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-27T16:17:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-27T00:18:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2751411782.2019
Area: Red Lake - Woodland Caribou Park, Kenora - Grassy Narrows - Whitedog, Sioux Narrows - Nestor Falls - Morson

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain at times heavy, and possible thunderstorms producing significant rainfall amounts expected tonight. Total amounts near 50 mm are expected over portions of the warned region, with locally higher amounts in embedded thunderstorms. The heaviest rain will occur tonight, but should taper to light showers by Tuesday and continue through Wednesday. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A slow moving low pressure system over northwestern Ontario will continue to bring significant rain to parts of northeastern Manitoba today and tonight. Further amounts of 20 to 40 mm can be expected by Wednesday morning over much of the warning area. The following rainfall totals have been reported from ECCC and Manitoba provincial forestry sites over the last 48 hours: (amounts in millimetres) Cross Lake 111 Pisew Falls 81 Jenpeg 78 Gillam 44 Kelsey Dam 33 Churchill 14 Rain will begin to taper off today over the Norway House and Cross Lake areas while the precipitation over northeastern Manitoba will continue into Wednesday. Neighbouring regions including York Factory and Island Lake will also see further significant rainfall amounts. Generally rainfall totals will be less than rainfall warning criteria. ### Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-28T00:42:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-27T08:43:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2081628727.2019
Area: Molson Lake and Bear Lake, Cross Lake and Jenpeg, Wabowden, Hwy 6 between Little Limestone Lake and Ponton, Norway House, Churchill, Gillam

properties.Title: Tropical Cyclone Information Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: For Tropical Depression Six. The next information statement will be issued by 03:00 p.m. ADT. Tropical Depression Six expected to become Tropical Storm Erin later today or tonight. Erin is then expected to begin tracking northeastward toward Atlantic Canada on Wednesday, likely bringing heavy rain and gusty winds to parts of the Maritimes later Thursday or Friday. 1. Summary of basic information at 09:00 a.m. ADT. Location: Near 31.2 North 71.7 West. About distance 575 kilometres southeast of Cape Hatteras NC. Maximum sustained winds: 55 kilometres per hour. Present movement: Southeast at 4 kilometres per hour. Minimum central pressure: 1010 millibars. 2. Public weather impacts and warnings summary. With Tropical Depression Six still over 1500 km and several days away from the region, details on impacts for Atlantic Canada can only be generalised at this time. Most of the impacts will depend greatly on the exact track the system takes through our region, which at this time is expected to be near the Atlantic coast of Nova Scotia Friday afternoon. a. Wind. Strong and gusty winds will likely accompany the system, especially to the right of and near the eventual track it takes through our region. At this time it is unlikely that winds will reach warning criteria in the region (i.e. gusts to 90 km/h or higher), but could still be strong enough to cause isolated power outages and minor damage, especially given trees are still in full leaf. b. Rainfall. Given the current forecast track, the greatest impact from this system will be rainfall, which could meet or exceed warning criteria (50 mm or more in 24 hours) in many parts of Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island, and southeastern New Brunswick. Maximum rainfall could locally exceed 100 mm in some isolated parts of these regions. Details will become more clear in the coming days as the system becomes better defined and draws nearer to our region. c. Surge/Waves. At this time, given the expected intensity and track of the system, significant storm surge and coastal impacts from high waves are not very likely. However, some higher than normal water levels and high surf are possible near and to the right of the track, and this will be monitored closely as the system evolves over the coming days. 3. Marine weather impacts and warnings summary. Gale warnings will likely be required for waters near and adjacent to the track Erin takes through our region later on Thursday and Friday. Based on the current forecast intensity, storm force winds are not expected at this time. Forecaster(s): Mercer/Borgel ### Please continue to monitor alerts issued by the Canadian Hurricane Centre and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-08-28T17:38:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-27T11:39:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0908965725.2019

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may damage some crops in frost-prone areas. A ridge of high pressure will build over western sections of the province tonight. Temperatures will approach zero degrees by Tuesday morning with some low lying areas possibly dropping below zero. ### Frost advisories are issued when temperatures are expected to reach the freezing mark during the growing season, leading to potential damage and destruction to plants and crops. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-27T13:33:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-26T21:34:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2926093160.2019
